title: How to evaluate an essay - Quora

response.answer_text: A few additions to Cathy’s suggestion of providing students with copies of the rubric you plan to use, so that they may edit and, in effect, pre-grade one another’s work: What I look for primarily is clarity and organization. A clear, well-organized essay starts out with a grade of 100%. From that, I deduct points for major errors (new paragraph in an awkward place, unclear antecedent for a pronoun, sentence errors) with fewer points deducted for minor errors such as spelling. A LITTLE MORE ABOUT ORGANIZATION I expect a high school sophomore’s introduction to a 3.5 essay to contain his/her thesis statement — that is, to tell me what I will learn from reading the rest of the essay — and his/her conclusion to “fit” the introduction in the sense of reiterating what I should have learned from reading it. I expect the middle three body-paragraphs to contain the student’s three main reasons supporting his/her thesis, each reason supported by at least two supporting details, with three details preferred. Note that students aren’t restricted to the 3.5 essay form. They may use any organizational pattern they choose, so long as the essay contains an introduction-with-thesis-statement, a conclusion, and three or more body-paragraphs which follow a pattern of the student’s own devising. Together, those paragraphs should lead readers to the writer’s conclusion. CLARITY The best essays are the clearest, those which can be read from start to finish without the need to re-read a prior sentence to puzzle out a pronoun’s antecedent or figure out what a misspelled word is struggling to become. The best essays also employ transitional words or phrases which keep the reader’s mental feet on the right path. Perhaps most important of all, the best essays convey a sense of the writer’s personality and, ideally, leave the reader feeling that s/he has learned something — gained an insight into the writer, for example, or even simply been entertained. They leave the reader feeling satisfied. Hope this helps! Carole Berlin

If you’re a new teacher and want some suggestions, Google “essay grading rubric”—i just did and got “About 595,000 results.” I did this when i first began teaching and then cherry-picked the things i liked best from a dozen examples. Whatever kind of essay will influence what you’re going to grade them on as will grade level and what you’ve been emphasizing in your lessons. Do pass out a copy of the rubric when you give them the assignment/prompt, imho. It helps them to see exactly what you’re going to grade them on and how much each part of the essay will cost (in points.) Make sure that anything you want them to pay careful attention to is more than 10pts, tho—otherwise, you’re going to get a few doofuses who decide, ‘the conclusion’s only worth 10 pts, and i can still get an A without it.’ Standard i remember was keep to large issues as much as possible and divvy the grade up among no more than 6 criteria. And remind them, of course, (on the rubric!) that essays are worth (insert percentage here) of their final grade, so they can’t say they thought it was just a standard daily grade. I used the rubric, too, a couple times in the drafting. That is, i had the students peer-review each other (twice, usually) using the rubric. Colored-pencil underlines help with this (red for off-topic content, blue for grammar/syntax errors, yellow for clarity issues….) Plus sparkly stars or some such for stuff done really well. Yes, these were high-school students. Yes, they loved the sparkly star stickers. (edited to add: Yes, they were expensive and yes they came of my own pocket.)
